work.p: This is a draft of the first four lines of a poem unpublished in Whitman's lifetime, titled "Pictures." The first several lines of the notebook draft were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310).

a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Originally titled "Pictures," this manuscript is a revision of the first four lines of a longer draft poem by that name, inscribed by Whitman in a twenty-nine page notebook. These lines were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in the 1881 edition of Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: "My Picture Gallery"

bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

add.l: With finger raised he points to the scattered prodigal pictures pictures

lg.l:
In a little house In a little house keep I
keep many
many pictures suspended hanging—It is not
a fixed house,

It is round—it is but a few
inches from one side of it to the
other. side.

But Yet
behold! it has room for
a its
picture of itself and for all these hundreds and thousands,—all varieties,
all the shows and memories of my life.
Here, do you know this? This is Cicerone himself; it is;
